According to a transcript of his prepared testimony, he will admit that Facebook has made mistakes on these issues, including privacy: "It's not enough to give people control of their information, we have to make sure developers they've given it to are protecting it too."

He will also talk specifically about the Cambridge Analytica scandal, where a developer created a Facebook quiz that it used to build detailed user profiles, which were later passed to the political data analytics firm against Facebook's policies.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is testifying before Congress this week to discuss the company's data privacy practices, as well as issues like fake news and Russian tampering in the 2016 presidential elections.
Zuckerberg has been thinking and talking about privacy ever since he built the predecessor to Facebook, called Facemash, at Harvard back in 2003.
When users of the service complained that their pictures were being used without permission, Zuckerberg took the site down and apologized.
But this is not a new issue.
